appeal against grant of injunction. constitutional law

whether s.80 of the trade practices act 1974 exceeds the legislative power of the commonwealth.  the constitution (62 and 63 victoria c.12) s.51 (xx)  trade practices act 1974 (cth.) s.52 , s. 80 .  trade practices
persons "aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring" contravention by corporation
whether evidence of persons actually being misled or deceived can be taken into consideration.  constitutional law
validity of provision enabling court to enjoin conduct aiding and abetting contravention

the constitution (63 & 64 vict. c. 12), s. 51 (xx). the appellant was the managing director of, and a shareholder in, a company engaged in selling land. the appellant had been restrained by order of the trial judge pursuant to s. 80 of the trade practices act from, inter alia: (1) aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring; and (2) inducing or attempting to induce the company to engage, in trade or commerce, in the conduct of advertising, representing, offering for sale or selling interests in land in a manner that was misleading or deceptive in contravention of s. 52 of the trade practices act 1974 . at the time the orders were made against the appellant, the company was in liquidation and was not a party to the proceedings.  on appeal,  held: per franki and northrop jj.

(1) since the head of power to legislate with respect to corporations clearly supports the provisions of s. 52 of the act, the legislature can, under s. 80 , prohibit a natural person from aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring a contravention of those provisions even in cases where s. 52 did not apply to the natural person.  r. v. judges of the australian industrial court; ex parte c.l.m. holdings pty. ltd. [1977] hca 6 ; (1977), 136 clr 235 ; r. v. goldie; ex parte picklum [1937] hca 65 ; (1937), 59 clr 254 , referred to.  (2) the trial judge was not in error in taking into consideration evidence of the state of minds of witnesses as to whether they were misled or deceived as evidence of actual deception is always relevant and can be taken into account in determining whether conduct is misleading or deceptive.  per keely j.

(3) the grant of the injunction under s. 80 is conditional upon an actual or prospective breach of s. 52 of the trade practices act or counselling such a breach, and is within the legislative power of the commonwealth.
misleading and deceptive conduct in relation to sale of land.  constitutional law
